title: Joffre-class aircraft carrier
text:
The "Joffre" class consisted of a pair of <a href="aircraft%20carrier">aircraft carrier</a>s planned by <a href="France">France</a> prior to <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>. Only one of the two vessels was <a href="laid%20down">laid down</a>, and neither was launched before the project was cancelled in 1940.
History.
"Joffre" was designed to give the <a href="French%20Navy">French Navy</a> a fleet carrier of greater capability than the existing . "Béarn" was hopelessly outclassed by the late 1930s as French aircraft carrier design had not kept pace with developments in other countries, and badly hampered by the fact it was not designed from the keel up as an aircraft carrier, but was instead a converted World War I-era battleship. "Joffre" was a design aimed at rectifying the deficiencies, but was still of limited capacity.
The lead ship was laid down on 18 November 1938, but the rapid arrival of <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a> led to a slow down of construction and the ultimate cessation of work that came in June 1940 as the country capitulated to German invasion. The ship was 28% complete when France capitulated. Work on was not continued by the Germans and the hull was scrapped. The second planned vessel of the class, "Painlevé", was never laid down. 
As the course of the war went, the lack of naval aviation did not become a factor for the French fleet, as France fell to land invasion before its navy could play a major role in the proceedings.
